{{Politics of Egypt}}
{{Politics of Egypt}}
â
A '''constitutional referendum''' will be held in [[Egypt]] on 19 March 2011,<ref>http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gLzgMRN5vmANBUJBTJJqvayXqWEg?docId=CNG.0f69b85278e292f4cec1b79291e88739.671</ref> following the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]. The 1971 [[Constitution of Egypt|constitution]] was suspended by the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] on February 13, two days after the resignation of [[Hosni Mubarak]]. The Council has organized a [[Egypt Constitutional Review Committee of 2011|committee of jurists]] to draft amendments to pave the way for new elections. The referendum will likely be held in March, with parliamentary and then presidential elections afterwards.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref><ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/27/us-egypt-referendum-idUSTRE71Q11620110227</ref>
+
A '''constitutional referendum''' will be held in [[Egypt]] on 19 March 2011,<ref>{{cite web|last=Zayan |first=Jailan |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gLzgMRN5vmANBUJBTJJqvayXqWEg?docId=CNG.0f69b85278e292f4cec1b79291e88739.671 |title=AFP: New Egypt PM addresses crowds in Tahrir Square |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-03-04 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> following the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]]. The 1971 [[Constitution of Egypt|constitution]] was suspended by the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] on February 13, two days after the resignation of [[Hosni Mubarak]]. The Council has organized a [[Egypt Constitutional Review Committee of 2011|committee of jurists]] to draft amendments to pave the way for new elections. The referendum will likely be held in March, with parliamentary and then presidential elections afterwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/27/us-egypt-referendum-idUSTRE71Q11620110227 |title=Egypt to call March referendum this week: lawyer |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
â
The proposed constitutional reforms include a limitation to at most two four-year terms, judicial supervision of elections, a requirement for the president to appoint a deputy, a commission to draft a new constitution following the parliamentary election, and easier access to presidential elections, either via 30,000 signatures from at least 15 provinces, 30 members of a chamber of the legislature, or nomination by a party holding at least a seat in the legislature.<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/commission-announces-proposed-changes-egyptian-constitution-0</ref>
+
The proposed constitutional reforms include a limitation to at most two four-year terms, judicial supervision of elections, a requirement for the president to appoint a deputy, a commission to draft a new constitution following the parliamentary election, and easier access to presidential elections, either via 30,000 signatures from at least 15 provinces, 30 members of a chamber of the legislature, or nomination by a party holding at least a seat in the legislature.<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/331837</ref>
â
The issue of limiting presidential powers was postponed until after the elections as part of the new constitution drafting process.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12589425</ref>
+
The issue of limiting presidential powers was postponed until after the elections as part of the new constitution drafting process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12589425 |title=BBC News - Egypt's army passes draft constitutional amendments |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
== The old articles from constitution ==
== The old articles from constitution ==
Line 111: Line 111:
===The Yes Camp ===
===The Yes Camp ===
{{expand section|date=March 2011}}
{{expand section|date=March 2011}}
â
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and the [[Salafi]] movement, among other Islamist groups in Egypt, think that the amendments are suitable for the time being and that the situation in Egypt is not perfect to write a new constitution right away. They have used fear tactics saying that '''Article 2''' of the Constitution of Egypt (which states ''Islam is the Religion of the State. Arabic is its official language, and the principal source of legislation is Islamic Jurisprudence (Sharia)''<ref>http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/chp_one/part_one.aspx</ref>) will removed or changed if they did not vote Yes. Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] advised the Egyptians on the 18 of March to vote Yes on constitutional referendum.<ref>http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=422881&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] also have asked their base to vote Yes.
+
The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and the [[Salafi]] movement, among other Islamist groups in Egypt, think that the amendments are suitable for the time being and that the situation in Egypt is not perfect to write a new constitution right away. They have used fear tactics saying that '''Article 2''' of the Constitution of Egypt (which states ''Islam is the Religion of the State. Arabic is its official language, and the principal source of legislation is Islamic Jurisprudence (Sharia)''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egypt.gov.eg/english/laws/constitution/chp_one/part_one.aspx |title=EgyptÃ¢â¬â¢s Government Services Portal - Egypt Constitution - Chapter one: The State |publisher=Egypt.gov.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>) will removed or changed if they did not vote Yes. Sheikh [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] advised the Egyptians on the 18 of March to vote Yes on constitutional referendum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=422881&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |title=Gulf Times â Qatarâs top-selling English daily newspaper - Qatar |publisher=Gulf-times.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] also have asked their base to vote Yes.
==Polls==
==Polls==
â
A poll done by the Egyptian government on its '''Information and Decision Support Center''' ''(IDSC)'' website said that 24,121 Egyptians (57 percent of the total number of voters) voted against the amendments, while 15,173 Egyptians (37 percent) supported them. Five percent were undecided.<ref>http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/348851</ref>
+
A poll done by the Egyptian government on its '''Information and Decision Support Center''' ''(IDSC)'' website said that 24,121 Egyptians (57 percent of the total number of voters) voted against the amendments, while 15,173 Egyptians (37 percent) supported them. Five percent were undecided.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/348851 |title=Majority of Egyptians against constitutional amendments, says poll | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-03-13 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
